title: 111_hr1387
content: The Act may be cited as the "Electronic Message Preservation Act" and it focuses on the preservation of electronic messages. The "Electronic Message Preservation Act" amends Chapter 29 of title 44, United States Code, to require the Archivist to promulgate regulations for agency preservation of electronic messages that are records. These regulations mandate electronic capture, management, and preservation of records in accordance with disposition requirements, accessibility for retrieval through electronic searches, and minimum functional requirements for electronic records management systems. The regulations require federal agencies to establish electronic records management systems for compliance, certify systems meet functional requirements, and ensure compliance within four years. Additionally, regulations cover other electronic records and mandate agency compliance. The Archivist must review the regulations. The Archivist is required to periodically review and update regulations related to electronic records management systems. Federal agencies must submit compliance reports to the Archivist, who will then report to Congress on agency compliance with the regulations. The Archivist updates regulations for electronic records management systems. Federal agencies report compliance to the Archivist, who then reports to Congress. A new item is added to the table of sections for chapter 29 of title 44, United States Code. The definition of "electronic messages" and "electronic records management system" is added to Section 2901 of title 44, United States Code. The definition of "electronic messages" and "electronic records management system" is added to Section 2901 of title 44, United States Code, which includes identifying records due for disposition and ensuring storage, retrieval, and disposition of records. SEC. 3. PRESIDENTIAL RECORDS. Additional regulations are being proposed for the management of electronic Presidential records during the President's term of office. This includes standards for records management controls to capture, manage, preserve, and ensure accessibility of electronic messages. The proposed regulations aim to ensure electronic messages are easily accessible for retrieval through electronic searches and require certification of the electronic records management system used by the President. Definitions for "electronic messages" and "electronic records management system" are provided in the amendments. The proposed regulations require annual certification by the Archivist of the President's electronic records management controls to ensure compliance with specified requirements. The Archivist must report annually to Congress on the certification status. The Archivist must report to Congress one year after a President's term ends on the volume and format of electronic Presidential records deposited and whether the electronic records management controls met the requirements. Effective Date: The amendments made by this section will take effect one year after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. PROCEDURES TO PREVENT UNAUTHORIZED REMOVAL OF CLASSIFIED RECORDS FROM NATIONAL ARCHIVES. The Archivist of the United States will establish procedures to prevent unauthorized removal or damage of classified records from the National Archives. This includes restrictions on viewing and handling classified records, requiring presence of authorized personnel or video surveillance at all times. All persons accessing classified records must consent to a search of their belongings after review. Notes and writings from non-authorized personnel will be retained by the National Archives until declassified or securely transferred. The section defines "records" and "covered personnel" as individuals with appropriate reasons and security clearances to access classified records. The amendment to Section 2204 of title 44 restricts access to original presidential records for individuals convicted of crimes related to handling archives. Additionally, there is a provision for budgetary effects of PAYGO legislation in this act. The budgetary effects of this Act, for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010, will be determined by the latest statement submitted by the Chairman of the House Budget Committee before the vote on passage.
